title-group.article-title: Artificial neural network based proportional plus integral plus derivative controller for a brushless DC position control system

abstract.p: Brushless DC (BLDC) motors are useful in applications such as process control, robotics, industrial automation, aerospace, electric vehicles etc. due to such advantages as the elimination of rotor losses and magnetizing current. Wider usage of BLDC motors demands optimum position control for high efficiency, accuracy and reliability. For an accurate position control, the estimation of moment of inertia and friction coefficient of the motor with load is essential. This paper incorporates the computation of the moment of inertia and friction coefficient of a BLDC motor with load at different load settings and emphasizes that load has an appreciable effect on the dynamic performance of the system. To obtain the optimum position control, a proportional plus integral plus derivative (PID) controller is employed and tuned using the PARR method. Artificial neural networks are used for computing the moment of inertia and friction coefficient of a BLDC motor with load and PID controller parameters at various load settings. Simulation results of the position control system are obtained at different load settings. From the results, it is evident that the PID controlled position control system responds to the desired position with minimum rise time, settling time and peak overshoot and is in dependent of load settings.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Computation of system parameters plays a vital role in the choice of the precise controller parameters in industrial applications. This is essential to fulfill the desired performance specifications of the system. Over the years, a great deal of research has been carried out in the computation of system parameters using genetic algorithm, fuzzy logic and neural networks. Moment of inertia and friction coefficient of the motor alone are estimated but that of the load are not considered though optimization, adaptive control and artificial intelligence techniques are employed (Despalatovic et al., 2006; Babau et al., 2007; Hadef et al., 2007; Al-Qassar and Othman, 2008; Kapun et al., 2008). The importance of estimation of load parameters is emphasized (Lin et al., 2010) but strategies for computing moment of inertia and friction of load are not discussed. Hence, proper computation of physical parameters of system is required for tuning the controller parameters. The viscous friction coefficient of the motor is computed while that of the load is not considered for precise position control tasks (Campa et al., 2008). Load parameters are obtained using genetic algorithm but friction coefficient of the motor is not considered (Zhang and Bai, 2008).

Precision and accuracy are very significant in tuning controller parameters to achieve the desired performance without affecting system stability. A system with its controller tuning based on motor parameters only without the load parameters (Kao et al., 2006; Nasri et al., 2007; Mallesham and Ramana, 2007; Sharifian et al., 2009; Nagaraj and Murugananth, 2010) may not yield the desired response in real time. Hence computation of moment of inertia of motor with load at different load settings is essential. The controller is tuned by considering the mechanical parameters of the motor with of the load in which inertia and friction are either known or specified. However, dynamic variation of load parameters for different load settings is not accounted (Dulger and Kirecci, 2007; Gokbulut et al., 2007; Ristanovic et al., 2008; Awadallah et al., 2009; Prommeuan et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2009).

This paper presents a simple and straight forward method to determine the moment of inertia and friction coefficient of a brushless DC (BLDC) motor with load at different load settings. Moment of inertia and friction coefficient are determined at ten different load settings using a SIMULINK model of a BLDC motor fed by a six step inverter. An artificial neural network (ANN) is employed to obtain these parameters at any load setting from no load to full load. Aproportional plus integral plus derivative (PID) controller is employed to optimize the performance of the position control system. Another ANN is used to obtain PID controller parameters at any load setting from no load to full load. Step response of the position control system is obtained at different load settings.

sec.title: 2. Determination of moment of inertia and friction coefficient of brushless DC motor with load
2.1. Methodology
sec.p: Electromagnetic torque Te developed by any motor is expressed by (1)Te=TL+JMdωdt+BMω where TL is load torque, JM is the moment of inertia of the motor and BM is the friction coefficient of the motor. The load connected to the motor has inertia JL and friction coefficient BL. Hence load torque TL may be expressed as follows (2)TL=JLdωdt+BLω
From (1) and (2) (3)Te=(JM+JL)dωdt+(BM+BL)ωTe=Jdωdt+Bω where J is the moment of inertia of motor and load and B is the friction coefficient of motor and load.
At steady state operating point, when the motor runs at steady speed (4)dωdtis zero.Hence(3)becomes,B=Teω

Since Te and steady state speed ω are known, the friction coefficient of the motor with load B can be obtained from (4). Speed of the motor drops from its steady state speed when the supply is switched off. Hence, (3) becomes Jdωdt+Bω=0. At t = J/B = τ, mechanical time constant of motor with load, the motor speed reduces from steady state speed to 36.8% of steady state speed.
Hence (5)J=Bτ
The moment of inertia of motor with load J can be determined by substituting the values of B and τ in (5).
Using the above method, the moment of inertia (J) and friction coefficient (B) of the BLDC motor with load can be determined from (5) and (4) respectively.

sec.title: 2.2. Determination of J and B at different load settings
sec.p: This section deals with the determination of J and B of a BLDC motor with load in a position control system in which the position of the load is to be controlled. The transfer function of the position control system (Ganesh et al., 2009) is given by (6)θ(s)Ea(s)=Kts[KbKt+(Js+B)(Ra+sLa)] where θ is the angular output position, Ea is the armature voltage per phase of a BLDC motor, Kb is back emf constant, Kt is torque constant, Ra and La are resistance and inductance of armature per phase respectively.
Specifications of the BLDC motor used for position control are mentioned in the Appendix.
The transfer function of the position control system is given by θ(s)Ea(s)=0.0368.64*10-9s3+5.184*10-6s2+1.296*10-3s

Figure 1 shows a SIMULINK model of a BLDC motor fed by a six step inverter used for the determination of the moment of inertia of a BLDC motor with load at different load settings. A 24 V DC supply is applied to the BLDC motor through a switch controlled by a timer. The gates of the respective switch in the six step inverter are controlled based on the states of hall sensor signals. The three-phase outputs of the inverter are applied to stator windings of the BLDC motor. The specifications of the BLDC motor are chosen in block parameters of a permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM) which is shown in Figure 2. Load torque (TL) is given as a step input of size corresponding to the desired load setting. The simulated electromagnetic torque (Te) and the speed responses of the motor are observed through the respective scopes. The mechanical time constant of motor with load is obtained from the speed response. Figure 1.
Brushless DC motor fed by a six step inverter. Figure 2.
Block parameters of permanent magnet synchronous machine.

As an example, electromagnetic torque and speed responses at no load are obtained and shown in Figures 3 and 4 respectively. From the speed response at no load, it can be found that the steady state speed is 5994 rpm and the mechanical time constant is 0.462 sec. From the torque response, electromagnetic torque atasteady state speed of 5994 rpm can be determined as5.47 e-3 Nm. Using (4) and (5), friction coefficientand moment of inertia of a BLDC motor with load arrangement at no load are obtained as 8.72 e-6 Nm-sec/rad and 4.03 e-6 Kg-m2 respectively. These values are in good agreement with the parameters used in block parameters (BM =1 e-5 Nm-sec/rad and JM = 4.8 e-6 Kg-m2). Similarly, the moment of inertia and friction coefficient of a BLDC motor with load are determined from no load to full load in steps of 10% using this method. They are tabulated in Table 1. It is required to compute the values of J and B at any load torque since the controller parameters for the position control system depend on J and B. This is possible with the estimated values of J and B for few values ofload torque from no load to full load as shown in Table 1.

ANN is one of the best tools to identify the parameters of any system in which the parameters have nonlinear variation with respect to some conditions. For the position control system under consideration, parameters J and B have nonlinear variation with respect to load torque. If the estimated values of J and B in Table 1 are used as targets, it is possible to compute J and B for any load torque using ANN training. Neural network architecture used for the estimation of J and B is shown in Figure 5. Load torque in the rangefrom 0Nm (no load) to 0.125Nm (full load) is used as input to the neural network. J and B from Table1 are used as targets in the neural network. The ANN training method used is Levenberg-Marquardt method. Thearchitecture of the ANN is a four layer network with one neuron in the input and two neurons (one for J and another for B) in the output layer. Three neurons are taken for each hidden layer. Tansig is the activation function for all the layers. The Levenberg-Marquardt training algorithm with mean squared error performance is used in a MATLAB file environment. This ANN is used for the estimation of parameters J and B in the SIMULINK model of the position control system. Figure 5.
Architecture of neural network.

sec.title: 3. Effect of load on system dynamics
sec.p: Using the transfer function of the position control system at no load viz. (7)θ(s)Ea(s)=0.0367.254*10-9s3+4.368*10-6s2+1.305*10-3s

Step response of the BLDC drive system expressed by (7) is determined by MATLAB simulation and shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Step response of position control system at no load.
Transfer function of the BLDC motor used for position control at full load is found to be (8)θ(s)Ea(s)=0.0365.634*10-9s3+4.198*10-6s2+1.786*10-3s

Using the above expression (8), step response of the BLDC drive system is determined by MATLAB simulation and shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Step response of position control system at full load.

From Figures 6 and 7, it is very clear that the valuesof performance specifications (rise time, settling time) of the BLDC drive system are different and they depend on the load setting. Hence, apart from moment of inertia and friction coefficient of BLDC motor, that of the load also has to be determined for evaluating the response.

Response of the BLDC drive sytem with the use of a PID controller is optimised at no load by Ziegler Nichols tuning (Parr, 1989; Vaishnav and Khan, 2010) followed by fine tuning and shown in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Step response of proportional plus integral plus derivative controlled system at no load.

Response of the BLDC drive system with the use of a PID controller is optimized at full load and shown in Figure 9. Response of the BLDC drive system is optimised at full load using the system parameters at no load and shown in Figure 10. From Figure 10, it is quite evident the response is not optimum as shown in Figures 8 and 9. This is because the PID controller parameters tuned for the no load model are used for the full load in Figure 10. This does not orient the system response at full load towards the expected level. This justifies that PID controller parameters have to be suitably tuned based on the transfer function of the BLDC drive system which in turn depends on mechanical parameters viz. inertia and friction of the motor as well as that of load. Therefore, accurate determination of the mechanical parameters of motor with load is essential to achieve the optimum response by suitable tuning of the PID controller parameters. Figure 9.
Step response of proportional plus integral plus derivative controlled system at full load. Figure 10.
Step response of proportional plus integral plus derivative controlled system at full load using controller parameters for no load.

Analysis of these responses clearly reveals that load has effect on system dynamics. Therefore, mechanical parameters of load at different load settings have to be accurately determined for evaluating the system response and tuning the controller parameters.

sec.title: 4. Proportional plus integral plus derivative controller tuning
sec.p: A PID controller is employed to optimize the performance of the position control system. The conventional Ziegler Nichols tuning rule is not used for obtaining PID controller parameters because the PID controlled system tuned using the Ziegler Nichols tuning rule is highly oscillatory. To achieve the optimum transient response without sacrificing stability, Ziegler Nichols tuning may further be fine tuned by a trial and error procedure. However, such a procedure is tedious and time consuming. To overcome this, the PARR tuning rule (Parr, 1989) is preferred since a PID controlled system tuned using PARR tuning has less overshoot.

Hence, PID controller parameters viz. proportional gain KP, derivative time Td and integral time Ti are obtained using the transfer function expression (6) of the position control system by the PARR PID tuning rule. The expressions used for tuning are (9)KP=0.5Ku (10)Ti=Tu (11)Td=0.2Tu

Critical gain Ku and period of sustained oscillations Tu are determined from the root locus of the system transfer function (6). Transfer function of the system from no load to full load is determined using the computed values of J and B from Table 1. PID controller parameters are obtained at each load setting using expressions (9), (10) and (11) from the root locus of the transfer function. These parameters are tabulated in Table 2. Table 2.

It is required to compute KP at any load. This is possible with the estimated values of KP for few values of load torque from no load to full load as shown in Table 2.

For the position control system under consideration, KP has nonlinear variation with respect to load torque. If the estimated values of KP in Table 2 are used as targets, it is possible to compute KP for any load torque using ANN training. The neural network architecture used for the estimation of KP is shown in Figure 11. Load torque in the range from 0Nm (no load) to0.125Nm (full load) is used as input to the neural network. KP from Table 2 is used as target in the neuralnetwork. Architecture of the ANN is a four layer network with one neuron in the input and one neuron in the output layer. Three neurons are taken for each hidden layer. Tansig is the activation function for allthe layers. The Levenberg-Marquardt training algorithm with mean squared error performance is used in a MATLAB file environment. This ANN is used for estimating KP in the SIMULINK model of the position control system. Figure 11.

sec.title: 5. Artificial neural network trained brushless dc drive based position control system
sec.p:
A SIMULINK model of an ANN trained position control system is shown in Figure 12. There are two closed loops in the position control system. One of the loops represents the position control system without a controller, and the other loop includes a PID controller. The actual position iscompared with the step position. The difference between the two positions is used as error input to the PID controller. The ANN architecture shown in Figure 11 is used to obtain KP at any load torque. The mean of Td and Ti in Table 2 are used respectively as Td and Ti in the PID controller block of Figure 12. Since the transient response for the given Td and Ti (i.e. corresponding to any load torque in Table 2) is the same as that obtained using mean Td and mean Ti. Therefore Td and Ti are not trained using ANN. Figure 12.
Artificial neural network trained position control system.

Load torque is given as the input for the estimation of J, B and KP. The ANN architectureshown in Figure 5 is used to obtain J and B at any load torque. Estimation of J and B is necessary since these parameters are used in the uncontrolled system as well as in the PID controlled system. Estimation of J and B, PID controlled system and uncontrolled system are highlighted in Figure 12.

The step response of the position control system is simulated by selecting load torque. The step responses of the uncontrolled system as well as the PID controlled system are observed from the respective scopes. Performance specifications viz. rise time, peak overshoot, settling time and steady state error are obtained from the responses.

As an illustration, load torque is selected as 0.09375 Nm (i.e. 75% of full load) in the load torque block of Figure 12. A simulation run of the position control system is made at this load torque. A transient response of the PID controlled system is obtained and shown in Figure 13. A transient response of the uncontrolled system is obtained and shown in Figure 14. From these responses, it is clear that the PID controlled system is superior to the uncontrolled system because the PID controlled system has a smaller rise time and settling time compared to that of the uncontrolled system. The load is varied from no load to full load in steps of 10%. Figure 13.

From Table 3, it is very clear that the PID controlled system yields an output position with a smaller rise time and settling time compared to an uncontrolled system at any load. Further, it is also evident that the performance specifications of the PID controlled system are in dependant of load settings because these specifications are constant at any load whereas performance specifications of an uncontrolled system depend on the load settings. Hence, it is evident that PID controller tuning is essential to achieve optimum response irrespective of load setting.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: The proposed method of estimation of mechanical parameters can be used to determine inertia and friction of a BLDC motor with load at different load settings. From the study of effect of load parameters on the system performance, it is found that load parameters have to be determined for any change in load. Because the load parameters also decide the tuning of controller parameters, and in turn the dynamic response of the system.

The proposed BLDC drive based position control system could yield optimum position control at any load setting. This is clearly evident from the simulation results of controlled and uncontrolled systems at different load settings. Further, the controlled output position is independent of load settings. ANNs play a vital role in tuning the mechanical parameters and PID controller parameters for any load setting. Proposed methods of estimation of inertia and friction with PID controller tuning can be effectively used for controlling the BLDC drive systems of different ratings. This method of position control can be extended to implement the real time position control system by employing appropriate measurement techniques for torque and speed and advanced processors. Auto tuning can also be done for the estimation of mechanical parameters and PID controller tuning in real time by employing effectively the concepts of state space approach incorporating state observers.
